question: Among parous women, does increasing placental weight across pregnancies reduce the mother’s subsequent risk of breast cancer? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: CONCLUSIONS Placental weight is positively associated with maternal risk of breast cancer.
content.source_2: Relative to women with placentas under 500 g in two consecutive pregnancies, those with placentas ≥700 g in both pregnancies had approximately a twofold higher breast cancer risk (adjusted hazard ratio 2.05; 95% CI, 1.15–3.64), with intermediate elevations when one pregnancy had 500–699 g and the other ≥700 g (HR 1.82; 95% CI, 1.07–3.08).
content.source_3: In a nationwide cohort of parous women followed for a median of 18 years, increasing placental weight across successive pregnancies was associated with a reduced incidence of breast cancer; women with placentas ≥700 g in both pregnancies had a lower risk than those with placentas <500 g in both (adjusted hazard ratio, 0.50; 95% CI, 0.36–0.70).
content.source_4: After controlling for birthweight and gestational age using time-dependent covariates, placental weight was not associated with maternal breast cancer risk (≥700 g vs <500 g: adjusted HR 1.03; 95% CI, 0.78–1.35; p for trend = 0.78).
